QNi4ZpODnMCHR49sHfYA5Q.text: Expensive but really enjoyed the spicy (spicy even for my immunized Chinese tastebuds) food, the amazing 33rd floor view of St Pauls, easy to drink cocktails, and cozy atmosphere.We were guided through the beautiful decor of red lanterns and mirrors to our cozy table facing the windows (aka the couple's corner, as we looked at our neighbors and they were all couples).  I made reservations a month in advance and could only score a 6:00 booking but we are always hungry.We ordered Shredded Chicken (£9) as a cold starter, which in a beautiful dish complete with spicy dressing.  Next we had the £15 minced pork, which came with several pieces of lettuce we used to coddle our pork babies.  Fish in spicy broth (think it was £20 something) we couldn't finish, as it was massive (like the waiter warned).  It was too salty as well, but the fish was cooked well, chewy but not rubbery.  We also had the £15 dim sum assortment which came with 2 pieces each of the following dumplings: rose champagne shrimp, scallop and pumpkin, crab meat, and vegetable and bamboo.  All of these were delicately wrapped and eaten quickly, leaving us to regret savoring the little expensive parcels.Cocktails were good, I really enjoyed Comfortable Numb (£12), a lychee drink with vodka and a peppercorn rim.  I must've been too excited about the peppercorn rim as even the waiter noticed the naked rim when he collected the drink after I was done.Check out the restroom before you leave for a cool view, and take a picture of yourself under the mirrored ceiling next to the lanterns before you head in to the restroom.  Overall we enjoyed our swanky experience, but if you're looking for more friendly prices and more authentic Sichuan, do check out the other restaurants around London (Sichuan Folk, Bar Shu, etc).

3ZfcoFaK9QyGaESSWWHL0Q.text: To be honest I wasn't expecting great food but took my parents for the view with the thought of £60/70 per head offering better value than £30 to just go up to the viewing platform at the Shard.  A nice super quick elevator took us up to the 32nd floor and we walked a flight up to the restaurant which was decorated very much like the Hong Kong sister restaurant in a dark traditional style.  For sure the views were great, even in the toilet, whilst service was friendly it wasn't quite attentive enough in certain areas, e.g. missing bowl, rice not served up by the waiter, tea was too weak and not refilled when required.  So onto the food, overall it was good, not great but good.  It serves northern Chinese style food so it's a nice change from the usual Cantonese affair served at most Chinese restaurants in London.  The spice has been tamed down a little for English tastes but everything was well balanced.  We went for dinner so didn't have dim sum but did sample mined pork and fennel seed dumplings which were a disappointment, the pastry was too thick and filling uninspiring.  Then onto the Roast Peking Duck which was looking forward too due to its rarity in England.  £38 seems a lot for 1/2 a duck but crispy skin wrapped up in thin pancakes is beautiful.  The duck was nicely flavoured and I was taken back to Hong Kong.  At £38 you get the fanfare of a chef slicing the skin off at your table, and then also a second dish using the meat of the duck to make a lettuce wrap duck dish.  Also good were the cuttlefish, crispy deboned lamb ribs, braised beef rib, and the seafood salted fish fried rice.  The spring greens were a little overdone but the fried prawns with salted egg and crab roe sauce were a revelation, simply amazing.  Even though not the best Chinese food I've ever had, it's good and wouldn't be disappointed at having to eat at Hutong again even without the views.  Definitely a place that ill impress loved ones, family or clients.  Despite dishes costing around £30 each it strangely does not represent bad value given the views and the fact that many of the dishes are had to find in restaurants in London.

cxkNIPAQxEDgMvlFttR4qw.text: Utterly amazing! As a new restaurant eager to please, I will say that the staff are what made this dining experience one to remember. We arrived for a lunch to which we were welcomed by several smiles and were catered for by attentive waiters throughout the meal. The view was somewhat marred by the typical English weather of course, with sideways rain and low lying cloud. However, the interior of the restaurant is stunning enough to make you even forget the 33 floors below you. But let this not detract from the real reason we were there, the food. A bolder statement may never have been said but this is by far the best dim sum I have ever had. The pure variety of unique creations made every mouthful a wondering journey. The signature dishes like the Szechuan crab and the 24 hour duck brought with it stunning presentation and served as a beautiful and memorable talking point.  Considering the number of dishes we cleared and the numerous bottles we drank, the bill came in very reasonable at just over £100 per head. For a special occasion this is the experience that you are looking for.

Q3KbMHDvSTsOhc9BJmYRag.text: Been there, done the Chard...Waiters are more snob than the mix of tourists and would-be jetseters. Pass...Some dishes are nice, not all.Tables are ugly and on the border of being dirty/broken.Generally overpriced for the experience.

lMRbYlHDVDc9A_nEO_V8VA.text: We went for lunch and had a little of the dim sum and the regular menu. The food was good but not amazing. The views are spectacular, which, I guess, is what you pay for. The service was very friendly and efficient.

06ovPVPhOb3C6fudPrz4mg.text: This place was absolutely wonderful. The food was amazing and our waiter, Manos, was extremely attentive. We ordered the Ma Lai Shrimp, which was spicy (if you like that sort of thing), a seafood fried rice, crispy beef, chicken and Louise beef. Each dish was nicely flavored and just melts in your mouth it's so good. And the view, there's nothing like it. You can see all of London from the restaurant, it's absolutely beautiful. We will definitely be back for sure.

YmpSWVb0owYUw2ZmM2dh5Q.text: Hutong is yet another restaurant that you have to book in advance... think just about one month's notice will do. It's perfect for a special occasion or to impress visitors to London with a gorgeous view of the skyline. For four people, we ordered half of a Peking duck, spicy minced pork with string beans, seafood fried rice with dried salty fish and ginger, spicy minced pork dumplings, and one bowl of rice. Of that, the least impressive were the dumplings... you get 6 of them, but they are terribly small and not well presented at all. While it's a relatively cheap item on the menu, don't waste your time on them, as you can get much better ones at even a hole-in-the-wall in Chinatown. The Peking duck is almost a must-do, as the chef comes to slice it at your table, and it comes with first the thin pancakes and then lettuce wraps with minced duck and sauce. The minced pork with string beans goes great with white rice, but do know that it is at least medium spicy, so be mindful. I found the seafood fried rice very delicious but some fellow diners were more cautious about the dried salty fish taste, and I can understand that it's not for everyone. I thought it was the perfect amount of food to share, and the price point basically depends on how many big fish/meat dishes you order, so ours came out quite reasonable. Great value at a stunning location.

Z1jUKPsW0VQ4i8jbwEEPiw.text: Had a couple of great cocktails in the bar area during an off peak time, and when we wanted to take 1 min to take a picture at the window of the adjacent and completely empty reservation dining area the staff member wouldn't allow it. We spent 35 pounds on 2 drinks and couldn't take one picture out window. No one was even in the area and hadn't been the entire time. Left angry. Have some consideration for your guests - we came for the view.

xvIWXwdwakZjUVxdIRIaeg.text: I took my fiance here as a treat and the evening did not disappoint. The reception staff and waiting staff were very friendly and we were tucked away enjoying our dinner for two in a very cosy and relaxing environment. The dishes looked very impressive and were delicious...although I am sure I can get similar quality dishes elsewhere for half the price. I guess you pay for the view! A very enjoyable evening and we'll be back for special occasions.

dcDTJBWlXXYUhRQ99kLM8A.text: If you're looking for amazing dim sum with an amazing view this is the spot! We ordered the set dim sum menu where you can choose 4 types of dumplings. There were 2 of us so we got 8. The lobster bun, the crispy prawns, the wagyu beef, pork soup dumplings, wonton dumplings ALL AMAZING!!! Definitely go here!

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom

5e9S111WB9J7s824xb3tEA.text: Excellent food, excellent ambiance and incredible house cocktails ( try the Knight Templar).Service was fast and knowledgable staff.

RCnrWRpU2gQARTkP2WYrvg.text: Awfully Chinese food with ridiculous price, let me explain why. I ordered Suan Ni Bai Rou (the sliced pork belly) which was served with a small plate of semi-liquid dark soy sauce!!! Allow me to explain why this is bad, the core of this dish is to demonstrate chef's skill in making a type of fresh-spicy sauce to light up the pork belly, it is difficult to prepare and requires experience of the chef. I was TOTALLY offended when Hutong serves this dish in such a odd way, no fusion, not being creative, simply stupid! Also, the Peking duck was sliced in very thick slices. It is meant to be thin, so that it will bit nicely when wrapping up in the pancake. Needless to say more this restaurant doesn't have the essential skills bookings a good Chinese meal. They are simply selling the view. I am rating this restaurant with 1 star because I could not believe why ppl rate it to high. In order to avoid a PR influence, I am giving my most original feedback and do not wish to encourage this restaurant at all! It should close!

leqlL9wBFwQDOR7jqxg2MA.text: Although there are many Chinese restaurants in London serving food as great at Hutong, you go here for the views to impress your guests (but you pay the price).  Excellent tasting menu and dim sum, one of the best roast ducks we've ever sampled. londonfoodiemama.tumblr.…

TRzkIClHUvd4i8Yi-Qllbw.text: An epic disappointment.A friend suggested we go here on a trip to London and we made reservations. We arrived with great expectations. We were seated in a covered area away from the windows. When you pay extra for the view and do not get the view, it is disappointing. Our waitress Maria was not personable and I felt like she viewed me as a check and not a person who went there for a special occasion. She was not personable or friendly. We were rushed and she detracted from the entire experience. The food was fair with the boneless lamb ribs and sole with vinegar and coriander excellent. The hot and sour soup was extra spicy hot and little sour. The vegetable spring rolls were dry and without flavor. The fried noodles with seasonable vegetables were greasy with only bean sprouts as a vegetable. I could go on but the rest of the food was as disappointing. The biggest ripoff of the night was our waitress offering to settle our 183 pound bill for 320 dollars. Given the exchange rate of 1.60 dollars to the pound, it was a hefty up charge. Run do not walk away from this overprice ripoff. The experience is not worth the time, effort or cost. I

N8kHaTKELr6Z3RaFnMykJw.text: Amazing food and service. The waiter's recommendations were spot on. Even the loo has a view. The only negative was the chairs are not very comfortable.

G8q-YCKrUoEE5nLOwzVCiA.text: Go for the views and the duck. The dim sum platter is also pretty good. Don't have many expectations for anything else, service or otherwise. I grew up eating amazing Chinese food made by my mother and the stuff here doesn't even come close.Also, only order as much as you can eat there because you're not allowed to take anything home with you - Shard policy which staff conveniently failed to mention when I was ordering. Not only a waste of money but also of food and resources that went into creating that food.Overall, overpriced food that doesn't even taste that great.

lw9vdESP_o0PW-4kfEHkBw.text: Hubby and I finally got to go here for dinner after making reservations two months ago. I was a little nervous given the previous reviews I read but could not help myself - I needed to give this place a chance myself. We started off with a glass of champagne and the whiskey cocktail with anise, both a good start. We then ordered the shredded chicken salad and wontons for appetizers, both spicy and delicious. We were getting full so wanted to order a couple of lighter dishes : ma po tofu and Kai lan with steamed rice, all of which were flavorful and light. We paired the spicy food with Sauvignon blanc, which was a good call to pair down any spiciness. We ended up being too full for dessert but would have gone for the black sesame seed glutinous balls -- miss those from San Francisco!  Yes it's pricey but so worth it got the experience, ambience, and tasty food!  PS. The service was great for me so I was very pleasantly surprised!

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Dinner at hutong

AOcl_k2AHmHiih9gNF703Q.text: It's been a while since I came here (l've been busy trying the Shards other restaurants) but I still like it. The view is amazing but that is true of all the restaurants at the Shard. I really enjoyed all the food. The crispy prawn roll starter was so good that a fight almost broke out over the last one. We also had a beef dish served over sticky rice & the Peking duck served in 2 stages which were both really good. It is a more expensive meal than the dim sum lunch special we got last time but if you take out the £100 on drinks then the food wasn't astronomical.

MPp84LPaO7U_49a6WiSfhA.text: Food: I have to admit that I was pleasantly surprised with the food at the Hutong.  Usually with fancy Chinese restaurants like this you're paying for the decor and view and the food is sub-par, but not here.  We did dim sum on a Saturday afternoon and ordered the pork shu mai, xiao long bao, pork puff, and a half order of duck.  Everything was delicious. Drinks: We ordered two soft drinks.Price: It's definitely not cheap, but then again you're paying for the whole experience.    For four people we paid 78.86 GBP. Ambiance: The restaurant is very nicely decorated, not cheesy at all.  The views of the city are amazing. Service: The service in the beginning was a bit slow, but once service got going it was better. Would I go back?  Yes.  It's a nice spot to take visitors to show off the city and have a nice Chinese dinner.

XSSCxEaTjSkcf2Pg144irQ.text: Of course you go up there for the view. And please do book for a time just before or after the sunset, so you'll get the day view AND the night view of the city.But we found the food excellent, too.Interesting dishes, nice service, spectacular venue. We were very pleased.

jAxBr_eAj84mkaPn1QcZcw.text: My lady took me here for my bday. Great birthday surprise for London . We enjoyed some soft shelled crabs, ribs, fried rice and noodles. I must say every dish was delicious. The crabs were spicy but very good. And the ribs had me licking my fingers in public. The staff was very friendly. And the view was breathe taking. So between the ambiance, staff, food and experience. I have to give this place 5 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Nice surprise at the end of dinner

a4M7_LTriZlk79z7vXZojQ.text: Great view, okay service, and sub-par food. We ordered Peking Duck (half), spicy shredded beef, and spicy pork dumplings. Still waiting for the spice to arrive from both the spicy dishes, and the duck was extremely sweet; add the sweet plum sauce to the supplied pancakes and you find yourself drinking water and eating boiled rice to assist in absorbing the sweet flavour. This was definitely not traditional Chinese cooking; and at a £110 price tag, not worth the exercise. The views are enjoyable and our waiter was extremely friendly. But still, for the price, two people can have a more enjoyable dinner elsewhere and not feel as if the pocket book has been raped upon completion.

-10j3nL7Di00BYBSPtExNg.text: The view was incredible but not much else. we took our friends there who were visiting from the states. We ordered the "whole duck" option which specifies that it's for 4-6 people. What we got I would say in total was 1/4 of a duck. They brought out the duck and sliced us a few thin slivers of what was mostly just skin! Then they told us that the second "half" of the duck would be brought to us in a different way. So they rolled the duck back into the kitchen and brought out a small plate of duck diced up and mixed with vegetables to have with the lettuce boats. In total I honestly think we ended up with barely 1 duck breast. It's just very misleading that they write "whole duck" and certainly make you pay for a whole duck then you hardly get anything.The portions were a joke and even though we ordered noodles and two appetizers in addition to the duck, we left the restaurant hungry.

wHG7Wn0M6cCuzioyPdp1hw.text: The dim sum was fine, but I'm not sure I'd go back for the dim sum. What I would go back for is the Peking duck. The skin was so crispy, it cracked like glass when you put it in your mouth. The chef will come and slice the breast for you at the table, and then he takes the rest of it away to fry it off with chopped onions and other things. The prawns in salted crab roe sauce were a little disappointing.. I was expecting a big salty hit, but instead was left with a bland grainy sauce on a fried prawn. I hate to recycle a cliché, but you really are paying for the view.. Stick to eating on the ground and getting a better meal.. I mean, it's great if you're trying to impress someone or going for a special occasion, but if you're going for the food, try it somewhere else... Service was friendly and quick - the only thing I thought was strange was that we were served our tea out of giant cups! The reason being 'that the restaurant had run out of normal teacups' ..so that's why we were served with high ball glasses.

RB_PGbBoYbnXdKpfot4kpQ.text: Despite being located on Level 33 of The Shard, we didn't hold the highest of expectations for Hutong. It was breathtakingly pricey for one thing - causing a bit of blind panic on my part at the sight of the menu, but I kept reassuring myself that View from Shard costs £25 for the privilege. I admit View from the Shard is twice as high up as Hutong but actually I felt the panorama looked very spectacular from the 33rd floor. You were high enough to see the whole of London spread out before you, but still low enough to see a good level of detail albeit from the unnatural vantage of South to North. Yes I am a north Londoner born and bred.So once the menu came, and we stopped distracting ourselves with the view (which took a while - there's so much view to be distracted by) there was much confusion and deliberation about what to order. Most dishes are quite highly priced, and the whole meal came to about £50 a head (without booze). We reckon with quite careful ordering you can get it down to £35. Tip 1 for Hutong on a budget - the portions are big and the staff do not warn you of this - we had so much left over at the end of the meal. Order less than you think you need.We ordered half a crispy duck as a starter - which is meant to serve between 2 and 3, and costs £30 - but actually it was plenty for four (or more) of us to eat - and after they carve it, they bring out the rest in a second delicious sitting.  I highly recommend this  on both taste and one of the better value menu items.My friend ordered the grouper broth for his main - a spicy fish soup which was too much for him to finish after filling up on the duck starter. And warning. If something on  the menu is marked as spicy, then it is woah mamma scorching hot - like this dish.Tip 2 - the price doesn't necessarily bear any resemblance to yumminess or the size of the serving. I ordered one of the cheapest items on the menu the jade tofu. At £9.50 it was also one of the best things we ordered and a decent size too. In illustration we also ordered the crispy deboned lamb at £31, and were so disappointed by the lack of seasoning or taste.Tip 3 - drink tea or juice.  Although yummy, cocktails and virgin cocktails are phenomenally pricey. Tea has the vantage of being refilled with hot water at no extra cost - the gift that keeps on giving.Loved the kai lun main and most of the veg dishes, but very much disliked the tasteless veggie soup noodle side. We also weren't impressed with the fact they refilled their Aesop soap in the bathroom with lesser inferior smelling products, and the ladies toilet doors being so tricky to manoeuvre and operate. However the boys do say they get to pee with a view so bonus points for that.  Overall the food was better than expected and you get a pleseant dining experience with the views, but now I've been there, done that and eaten at the Shard I am in no rush to return.

SHXFW8xPJyYA5bcL4r-12Q.text: Great experience! I visited Hutong with my best friend a couple of days ago for my birthday. Everything was perfect from the tasty food, to the attentive polite and caring staff, the cocktails and of course the views! I honestly could not have wished for a better experience. I'd highly recommend Hutong. We go out to fine dining restaurants often and this has truly been one of the very best.

txp2d8FgZBrtd2HDgs4UWA.text: Came here last night my birthday. We made the reservation 2 months in advance so was very much looking forward to it. It did not disappoint and had a lovely time. We had a great window table view. Service was friendly & gave good recommendations for food & if something was really spicy. It is pricey- but you are also paying for the atmosphere and view. We ordered a variety of food. As a veggie had a lot of options for me. Food Ordered: Vegetarian hot & sour soup: Really lovely! Not too spicy and had a lot of flavour. Dover Sole & Coriander soup: My husband ordered this and really enjoyed it.Vegetable Spring rolls: Enjoyed these but served with Chinese vinegar so can be quite bitter. Vegetable Dumplings: Good but a bit mushy. Did not have a lot of flavour.Ma Po tofu: Spicy but really good! I was advised before ordering it that it would be spicy so asked to do it lighter on the spice. It was still very spicy though.Egg fried rice: Was really good- one portion is enough to share between 2Lotus fried root: Was too spicy. Would not order again. Asked for light on spice but was still too unbearable to eat. I was quite excited to try it too after reading all the rave reviews. I love spicy food but this was too spicy for me.Blueberry cheesecake: We shared this at the end- was lovely as blueberry was baked into the cheesecake.We shared a bottle of the Zinfandel, Sebastiani, Sonoma County red wine. It was great & they kept it a perfect room temperature. They have a bar as well to the right hand side that has a variety of tables that also have window views that are first come first serve. It was a great evening- we will definitely return again for a special occasion.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. View from our restaurant table.
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian hot & sour soup.
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Bar view

J8IO4o_U9PhS7g1aBKHeXQ.text: Everything was delightful.Our party of 7 was seated in a private room with lovely panelling. The vegetarian dumpling was good, though nothing special. The food improved from there, though.The spring rolls were sliced diagonally in half. For a simple staple dish, they were very good. The shell was crispy and flakey, and the veggies moist.For entree, I had the grouper with black bean sauce. Delicious. Dessert was less impressive, but still good. The lychee sorbet was light and refreshing. The fried red bean paste tasted good but didn't wow me. The golden dumplings made our dairy-free dining companion happy, which was good because it was the only dairy-free item on the dessert menu.

vG2jQd8zJWUUHjcSQEgjcw.text: Have been quite a few times. Great view and good place to invite friends traveling to London. Best to ask for a table by the window and enjoy the day from sunset to night.Food is OK. The 'haitong seafood rice' is quite disappointing. Others are good overall especially the dim sum at lunch time. Dress smart casual.

yGkoIy4bN83rTWXcD3Lsww.text: Went to the bar here, let me summarize:  pretentious door staff, check (we were told to dress casual smart 'next time'). Cheesy decoration, check. Overpriced drinks, check. Not enough stools on the bar, check. Best seating area in the whole place closed for no reason, check. Bathrooms with a great view while you pee, check. Try it out, be disappointed by yourself.

2vQ45rTloL8D2orxQDpGrQ.text: Unfortunately there are not very many truly excellent Chinese restaurants in London and Hutong follows that trend. It's main selling point is its location in the Shard but the space is awkward and not particularly comfortable. They have attempted to partition it using screens but I'm not sure that's the best strategy given that you want to see the view. The bar is small and cramped, so better to go to the one in Aqua down the stairs.Food was fairly ordinary. It is nominally Northern Chinese but comes across as pan-Chinese with Szechuanese dishes such as ma po tofu etc. The quality of the ingredients was excellent but otherwise it was all rather unexceptional. The staff were friendly and adequately efficient. Overall an underwhelming experience, which is not what you want when you are paying top-end prices.

4ghIb4uJoOMlfWohwDhjkA.text: Having been lucky enough to have been to some pretty smashing restaurants for a 26 year old, I have to say this is amongst my top 3 restaurants all time. It helps that my boyfriend took my there as a surprise for my birthday ;-)We stopped for a cocktail first. The view was stunning, I would definitely go back just for a drink. We were then taken up to the above floor to our table where we went for the set menu. You have to ask for this menu as they don't give it to you spontaneously. We had seen it online so knew to ask.Each course was absolutely de-li-cious to the point that some of the tastes have popped up in my dreams more than once since that night ! I particularly enjoyed the spicy crab.... Devine. We splashed out on wine too.I loved the way the dishes were placed on the table for us to share, but beware slow eaters, make sure you get your share ! This is not a place for generosity ;-)Unfortunately I have to say that despite the 5 stars the service was only just ok. We felt a little rushed and even looked down on - but it didn't put us off. One of the servers was lovely which made up for the others being a tad rude - or at least not particularly nice. It is a shame as the night would have been even more special had we not felt that one discomfort but never mind the food and whole experience was dreamy. The price of course was high but it was expected and as a one off treat it was well worth the spend.Can't wait to go again - even the view from the toilets is epic !

IxdYTIfbXQ7kqiKGmRc_sA.text: Haid is fantastic as a server at the lounge.  Probably the best bartender we have ever met or been served by!   Fantastic location, excellent service and food and mixology!!

VwSAJ7oAFV7UfMuC2zqHTw.text: Located on the 32nd floor of the shard. Walking in we saw several lines around the shard, presumably one is for the view, another is for the restaurant. Upon walking in we were asked if we had reservations, we said no and indicated we just came in for the bar. We were directed to the 32nd floor. There were no lines and the view was spectacular. Coming here for drinks is a really quick and easy way to go to the shard and avoid the lines and hastle. The bar area itself is quite small and pretty busy at 2:30 in the afternoon on a Saturday but not too busy where you're elbowing people. There were a few tables in the bar area and having patiently waited for about 15-20 minutes we were able to snatch one up. Got a drink each. The Hemingway was delicious. The bar staff carefully created each drink with the utmost attention to detail. Obviously presentation was key to them. The decor is very aesthetically pleasing. The only comment I would have is that the bartender after making each drink would go through the extra trouble of pouring more ice on top to make the drinks look full. He was making the drinks right in front of the customers and would top it off with a handful making a mountain of ice on top. Your not fooling anyone and the ice melts anyway so why clearly pour more in, just get the amount right  the first time and pour the mixed drink on top your just making a mess and getting your hands all over someone's drink. The table space is about 5 tables can seat 2-4 but a lot of people moved tables and chairs together to accommodate larger groups so hard to tell for sure.Overall great experience for a drink and a view

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Hemingway

wMr9FBBJ48WQOt85qNP5mg.text: This place is...over-the-top in terms of people and decor, and underwhelming in terms of actual food and drink.Our server was chatty, sure, but actually talked so much that he forgot simple requests such as "could I have another dim sum menu for my table of 5?"  He also tried really hard that he made a crude joke about their bathrooms and the Thames.  I'll spare you the details, but seriously, not something I needed to hear while trying to enjoy my lunch.The manager (a tall Englishman) actually bowed and said "ni hao" to me and my sister when we walked by.  Sure, we look Asian, but c'mon, ask any Asian girl who grew up in an English speaking country and we'll tell you it's kind of presumptuous and rude for someone to feel like "ni hao" is an acceptable greeting for us.The food itself was pricey and not very delicious.  If you want good quality dim sum in London at a more high-end establishment, I'd strongly recommend Hakkasan in Mayfair.  This was not comparable at all.  One of the dumplings tasted like it had cottage cheese filling!  The overpriced cocktail my friend got can be summed up as a £14 champagne flute of Sunny-D with alcohol.  The tea selection was not as good as Hakkasan, either, now that I think about it.The straw that broke the camel's back was at the end, my husband went ahead to pay for our table so we could treat our guests who were visiting London.  This was done discreetly to avoid our guests wanting to pay.  The waiter (same one with the Thames bathroom joke) came by shortly after and said in disjointed Mandarin (and I will translate into English now) - "This foreigner has paid the large bill for your table."WHAT. THE. EFF.

luencmd0eYxKARvsMqSWiA.text: It is another trip to the shard for dinner at Hutong....yes another trip and this time to take a good friend from abroad to see a 360 degree view of London. But also to have one of London best place for Peking duck.I have been to Hutong for both lunch and dinner. But I definitely prefer the restaurant for their dinner menu than the dim sum menu. The restaurant is based on food inspired from Northern China so there are many spicy dishes on the menu but also there are some non-spicy dishes to balance taste buds.When you visit Hutong, you have to try the Roasted Peking duck which is come either half or whole, and is severed in two stages. The chef will thinly sliced the duck in front of you and lay on a piece of wood lined with banana leaf. This is served as the first stage of the dish where you wrap the duck with cucumber, spring onion and hoi sin sauce in pancake. Second stage of the duck will come as part of the main dishes which is where the left over meat is diced and stir-fried with red onions and peppers. You wrap the dish with hoi sin sauce in crispy lettuce.The evening I took my guest from abroad there was unfortunately no chilled spiced razor clams. This is a nice appetiser to start the meal, although I do prefer it being slightly warm. Instead we ordered the thinly sliced pork belly with cucumber slices with chilli and garlic sauce. This is also another cold dish but is bland if you do not have it with the sauce.Hutong has a varieties of alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks to order, whether you enjoying them at Hutong's bar or accompany with your food. But I always feel if you are having a Chinese meal it is always best to have it with Chinese tea. However, if you need to cool down from the spices then I do love the lychee juice.

DSNY3EwdJNNpUwO_7-U4Tw.text: I took my little sis here for her birthday lunch as a treat. It was a fantastic treat indeed! It absolutely blew us away from beginning to end. First, we had a seat right by the window (there aren't actually that many, so I was really pleased that they had taken into consideration that it was a special day.) The view was stunning and almost stopped any conversation as it was so interesting. It's a great height - high enough to see for miles, but low enough to actually see details. The service was friendly. They took on board that it was my sister's birthday and made her feel really special. They were helpful with recommending dishes, extremely flexible and just lovely. The food was scrummmmmmy! I don't usually like chinese food, but I loved everything we ordered. We had: Crispy peking duck rolls (very crispy!) Baked Wagyu beef puffs (my sister's favourite) Rose champagne shrimp dumplings (my favourite - so tasty) Sautéed crispy shredded beef and chilli (recommended and oh so naughty, but good!) Tofu with chilli sauce (not actually as hot as advertised - it came with a health warning! - but really delicious!) We had a bottle of viognier, that was both extremely reasonable (almost cheap!) but absolutely delicious. The only criticism in ordering was that there was so much literature to get through and different options. We were spoilt for choice, but our waiter helped us make some excellent choices! We were running out of time, but decided to go for coffees as they smelt amazing! With our coffees, they served my sister a bowl of ice cream and a happy birthday chocolate! It was such a sweet touch! We loved it, and I highly recommend going on a Saturday lunch time - nothing is too busy (unlike weekday evenings) and you actually get to see the view in daylight.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Very chilli tofu!
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Spicy crispy beef
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Pink champagne shrimp dumplings (you can see the wagu beef puffs in the background. We had eaten one!

j7cWpkFluCmkcrdz0sY7ag.text: We have been here twice, once in November 2014, where we sat in the bar area having great drinks and different kinds of dim sum and the second in April of 2016, where we had an amazing dinner which included the best Peking duck we have ever had as well as crispy beef tenderloin. Service was great. One of the highlights is the outstanding view of London as you are at the top of the Shard building. You can even see the view from the bathroom!  If you really want to imprrsss someone or splurge for a great night out, I highly recommend this place.

G5LyqBM225dcerafooo63Q.text: Exquisitely dim sum-Chinese style afternoon tea with a beautiful view of London from the Shard 33rd floor. Incredible food presentation the duck roll is especially delicious. Dan-Dan noodle not so loyal to the original dish, but otherwise everything is made with a lot of thought and effort. Generously the flavour is strong/spicy but not too strong it can't be handled. Unobstructed view from 33rd floor of the Shard especially pleasing to the eye of you sit by the window. Really lovely sunlight~

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom

uCAIv5l_AfURWUhBiULwYg.text: Impressive panoramic view from the 33rd floor of The Shard and nice themed decor, but unfortunately everything else about this restaurant is disappointing. I've been to the Hutong in Hong Kong before and had a really lovely dinner there, so I was excited to try the London location as well. It was a huge letdown and I'm still wondering how this restaurant managed to fail so badly. The dishes we ordered weren't terrible, but at such high prices I would expect nothing but excellence in execution. The shrimp dumplings were actually quite tasty, but there were many things wrong with some of the other dishes we ordered, such as the green onion pancakes (very bland and flavourless), conpoy and egg-white fried rice (hard undercooked rice, and I didn't notice ANY dried scallop in the dish at all), and seasonal vegetable fried noodles (bland, overly greasy, and far too many bean sprouts). Tea selection was extremely poor - our server listed off white, black, and pu erh tea. This is supposed to be a Chinese restaurant...WTF?!?!? Service was poor and awkward. While not inattentive or rude, the whole experience ultimately felt substandard. Our server constantly mumbled and I could never quite tell what he was saying. While dishing out individual portions, he would also hover extremely close over me as I was eating. He also failed to bring out bowls for our fried noodles, and would interrupt awkwardly at random times throughout the meal. This place is just sad and overpriced. Go to Hakkasan instead if you're looking for upscale Chinese food.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Seating
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Crispy duck roll
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Shrimp dumplings

p4_a8V7ny1sHmSnXwT7kzg.text: My sister took me here for my birthday and I loved it!If you're somebody who is afraid of heights - like myself - eating 33 floors up could be a challenge while eating! Having said that,the view is amazing and still very much appreciatedMy sister ordered for us but I remember their roast duck and it was something else! Can't go anywhere and find one like itService was great, and food was presented beautifullyWould definitely recommend to everyone specially for a special occasion

VpBC_9f3WfPfImMyCUtr-g.text: I would go back in a heartbeat, so allow me to quickly explain 3 stars...(a) the place is AMAZING in terms of views and ambiance through the door.  There are very few better and more accessible venues to soak up such a view on a clear day or night.(b) You can get in dressed relatively casual, and don't need a reservation - a bit of a secret that most don't know about the SHARDBUT(c) The drinks (as expected) are WAAAAY over-priced(d) It's nearly impossible to get a seat in the evening(e) people stalk for seats so even if you're in there, you have to play a game for 30 minutes to sit anywhere, and inevitably get into a British fight (read: uncomfortable staring match, tension in the air, but do your best to pretend like it's not there while stealing the occasional harsh-but-not-obvious glance at the perpetrator of your misery) over seats.(f) The bartenders act like you're not even there, and it takes FOREVER to get a drink even if you're first because they're just not really that good or fast at pouring drinks.(g) the urinals have this weird thing in the evening where the external glass of the building reflects the view of the people standing right next to you (and you to them...) from *ahem* non-traditional viewpoints that should typically reserved for Soho bars.(h) and the big standing table by the bar moves - NO LEANING!!  So not only can you not get a seat without eye-fighting, you cannot lean unless you team up with all of your fellow seat-stalking foes (unlikely as it might be) to strike the perfect balance lest someone's extra 5 lbs of pressure sends you all for the floor...until, of course, a seat pops up, and then you best be on your game, because this cake walk only ends in two ways: you getting your seat, much to the displeasure of your leaning coalition of fellow post-holders, or you end up face-down being trampled by angry bar elephants awaiting their snout-wetters now for 30+ minutes.Good luck, my future seat-seeking foes...good luck.

B43tW8okK_NG9ItEGVEAUg.text: I had family visiting from America and thought it would be nice to visit the shard for a few drinks. It was everyone's first time visiting and we decided to try Hutong on the 33rd floor. Upon arrival we were approached by a server who offered us 2 tables for 2 as there were no table of 4 available. However we noticed a table of four opening up and decided to stand at the bar and wait. We were then told by the server that we needed to move so she could "do her job without us in her area". I understand that she wanted us to move but she could have said it a bit nicer. We moved to the table and ordered some cocktails, I got a NuWang (pronounced New Wong) the drink tastesed of cucumber, elderflower, and a kick of Chili it was very nice and very refreshing. My sister ordered their take on a Bloody Mary and she enjoyed it despite it being quite small. Overall the view is amazing, the drinks are flavourful but very expensive. I was a bit put off by the service and I will probably try the other bars in the Shard before returning to Hutong.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Two NuWang cocktails, the passion fruit and mango cocktail and a absinthe based cocktail. All priced between 15-18 each.

A9wn2g2AQLszDLc_OLg-aw.text: Overall-good. Very impressive decor. Vibe was trendy and deep. One of our bottles of sparkling water disappeared after the first poor. And the first bottle of wine was late. But otherwise good vibe, food and service. View was amazing.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Dinner

DkvBnxduFkW992jDEllojA.text: I went there for lunch time with my family. We had to go through the security check in order to enter the building. The elevator doesn't need us to close the door. It will automatically closed, it only takes 15seconds to 32floor. Everything looks fancy and modern. However, I really don't appreciate the server. We went when the restaurant just opened, only a few tables were being seated. We were trying to take pictures, can't find one server. There was one server saw us, then he looked away. As a fancy dinning restaurant, this is certainly not the quality that they should have. They said they only have one type of tea-jasmine. We see other tables have a pot tray and we don't. The soup dumplings were decent though. The seafood fried rice is quite interesting. It is one of their signature; however, it doesnt have eggs. At first, we thought, it must taste blend, but no! Not at all!!! The rice has a taste of the seafood freshness. The only negative is that, not much seafood was in it.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom

Xv8BPdMFzP8lckrbze5I3Q.text: Ordinary food with ridiculously high price,Peking duck was not sliced thin enough. You can have the same taste or even better dim sum in most restaurants in china town.I don't understand why it is always fully booked.not worth the money.Service was good,staff are friendly and helpful.However we believed the water glass was not dried properly after wash,it smells.Great view,but I'd rather go Aqua bar next time.

h_h1UBCjX4r9JBHMPpWSWQ.text: Excellent view. Food complimented the view. Prices were more for the view than the food  - somewhat on the high side. But overall it wasn't disappointing ..

DgX8imZziAmjBJvSIlvWkA.text: What do you get your mum who is impossible to buy for? Every birthday and Christmas is spent frantically thinking what to get her. So when my husband suggested taking my parents to Hutong, we booked immediately a late Sunday lunch.Unfortunately we had the worst weather ever, pelting rain and really cloudy. But hey what can you do in winter. Despite the rain we were pleased to get a window table. The menu isn't vast but we did struggle to pick. As there was 4 of us we chose the set lunch menu.Monkfish and enoki mushroom soup - tasty, similar to sweetcorn soupDim sum dumplings: xo sauce and prawn, sea bass and shrimp, scallop and kai lan and pumpkin - I was sadly every excited to get my own bamboo steamer to myself (I get twitchy when I have to share food). They were really beautifully made and almost too pretty to eat. My favourite was the xo sauce and prawn dumpling.Wagyu beef puffs - light pastry with a sweet tender filling, lush!Prawn and cuttlefish in a pickled chilli sauceChicken, string bean and oyster mushroom lettuce wrapsKai lan in ginger saucerEgg white fried riceThe portions were very generous. The prawns and cuttlefish were delicious the right level of spice, but be careful of the the chilies I ate a really hot one. The kai lan was perfectly cooked and the lettuce wraps were delightful. The fried rice was nice and light and the perfect accompaniment to the dishes.We had jasmine tea with the meal so with dessert my dad and James had a beer and I had a glass of bubbles to see the new year in. I chose the golden sesame dumplings with apple and cinnamon purée, my mum and James had the glutinous black sesame dumplings and my dad had the honey and ginger ice cream. My dumplings which I would call sesame balls were amazing! Hot crispy sesame coating with a light apple filling, my mum being mum said that isn't Chinese, true but it was lovely. The glutinous dumplings which are very like moochi were delicious, soft and gooey with a lovely crumbly coating which gave a bit of texture.My mum and dad were very impressed with the quality of the food and the generous portions. This isn't always an easy task with my parents!As I said at the beginning we had awful weather. During the meal, the rain slowly eased and the sun made a little appearance breaking up some of the cloud. If you came on a clear day or evening you would definitely get some fantastic views of London, and I have a real soft spot for a view of London. I would love to come back for cocktails on summer evening. There are also some lovely private dining areas, which would be fantastic for a large group dinner. Can't wait for an excuse to come back!

WbqnH2GfEkkRkMO29TaTUw.text: Came here for drinks and to see the view. We stood at the bar for a few minutes where only one bartender was working. He was busy and when he finally looked at us, he asked us to have a seat. Another 15 minutes passed until someone came with a drinks menu. 20 minutes until we had our drinks. The waitress put the check down a minute after she delivered our drinks. We finished our drinks, tried to pay, and waited nearly 20 minutes until we could flag someone down. 50 quid for 2 drinks and some nuts, and the view is just not as fun when you're being ignored. I'd see London from up above some other way if you are planning to visit.

bS8hjnYCox11svaucFxJFw.text: My friend chose this bar for leaving drinks and this was a great bar. It did take a while to get served at the bar, but the cocktail I ordered (Golden Dragon) was simply delicious! Great view (as expected), lovely decor and would definitely go there again.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Vino
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. View
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Cool interior above the bar

HQVqztJBsVv7M5Ux5AhhJw.text: Most of the tasting menu you could get at a standard Chinese restaurant in LA at a third of the price, but you're paying for ambiance. The Shard is the tallest building in London and the views are pretty spectacular  of the river, London and Tower Bridge,  and London City (compares to Chicago's John Hancock Tower view). The highlight was definitely the crispy duck and pork, as well as the kung pao shrimp with sichuan peppercorns.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Kung pao shrimp

hBfpz-h1II5CfjPMoZF2hg.text: Not worth it. Best part was the cocktails, at 17 pounds each they should be. The staff here is what's lacking. They forgot my order twice and what was brought out wasn't spectacular. We ordered the set menu, and the only good item was the dim sum.  The crab was limp, the beef dish wad flavorless and dry, rice was hard. For the price this is nothing like hakkasan so go there if you have the desire for upscale chinese. This place is a bust.

YO-DoPBmGwXK3TVoFJpF3w.text: The ride to the 32nd floor, and one flight of steps to the 33rd, was quick, to say the least. The view is overwhelmingly spectacular, of course. Tinsel town London looks gorgeous, the newly manhattanised City of London stands out, and Canary wharf can also be seen in the not so distant horizon. The cocktail menu is interesting, super original and mostly delicious. £12-14 per drink. The Golden Dragon with a huge slice of dragon fruit is delicious, nicely tangy and refreshing.The starters look good, but because issues with general consensus  around getting plates for the table, we got the chicken with the little Chinese bread thingy, and a full portion of the Kung Po Chicken (which by the way, is not a starter on the menu, but is positively delicious. The mains were not too bad, but nothing to write home about. The sesame dumpling with an apple and cinnamon filling was not bad, the goner and honey ice cream was a let down.I'd give more points to Hakkasan, but people have disagreed with me, so it's probably a very very subjective assessment.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom

YgSLkX6PB0uPc5Gx6d__VA.text: Amazing views ! No doubt about that but the food ? I'm not sure . The roast duck came in 2 different servings (which is spoilt) as I didn't realise at first but when it did come I did not like it when they diced it and stir-fried with onions?!? (Why?) so the manager did find out I didn't like the way it was cooked and sent another half roasted duck again for free of charge but by now we already had our main courses and the main course isn't all that either. I have to say I won't come back to this place at all but for the views I may go to different restaurants or the Shangri La hotel . So 3 star is for the view and the customer service but the food no thanks !

mvBuL7LT5j8Lo1gly_i-9Q.text: This is a place to go when you have out of towers visiting London, our friends took us here and we were happy that we didn't have to buy tickets to see the view from the Shard. The service is good. The food is predictably good. We ordered the fried crabs and veggie dumplings both of which were sufficiently good. Then we had try Ma Po Tofu, string beans, spicy fried rice and the beef wrapped in lotus leaf. My favorite dish were the string beans, the spices on that were bang on. The beef looked very fancy but was just good. We also had a chocolate tart for dessert, we felt that the tart shell was undercooked and they were really good, taking it away and not charging us. Overall we had a good time, the view is unbelievably good and the ambience is trendy. Go for the whole experience. The food by itself might not be a draw

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. The tart which was actually very undercooked

g6Vc8qLViKYG7-s_StR01g.text: Plenty of atmosphere including some bright spark who decided to bring a screaming toddler to the restaurant at 8pmThe food is tasty without being spectacular.A bit pricey although given the location that's not a surprise.Service is good but don't overstay your time slot or you'll be politely asked to leave.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Hutong at The Shard
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom

zN6cXntTF5JmBkq6PssY5g.text: Our first choice was to go to the viewing deck on top of the Shard.  But it was booked full for sunset.  So plan B is to go to the 32nd floor and have a drink at the restaurant.  It was packed, of course.  If you see someone leaving, dash for the table.  The view is great.  See the sunset reflection on the skyline and see the Tower Bridge glow in the setting sun.  The prices for the drinks are reasonable to me.  This is a place for drinks with a fantastic view.  The waiters are friendly and cute.  Worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Drink up the view
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. View from the 32nd floor of Hutong

NqBUDWUZOua2AL1xAHJYoQ.text: This evening we had dinner reservations for the 3 of us at Hutong. If I'm being honest I wasn't that excited about dining at Hutong. I thought dining inside the Shard would be unique and offer us amazing views of the city. In the end the service, food, ambiance, and views wowed us!When you enter the Shard you have to go through a security scanner and then the staff check your name and reservation and show you to the elevator. The three of us checked in and were helped with our coats. We were a little early for our reservation so we opted to enjoy a cocktail in the lounge. The lounge service was a little on the slow side but the relaxing environment and the delicious drinks made up for it. Before we could settle our bar bill we were told our table was ready. The staff helped carry our drinks to the table and instructed the staff to add our drinks to our dinner bill. Our table was right up to the windows offering us fantastic views of London. The ambiance was low lighting, dark wood, red lanterns and welcoming staff. We ordered vegetarian spring rolls and Iberico pork dumplings to start. The starters were hot, savory, and delicious. For entrees and side dishes we ordered dan dan noodles, roasted Peking duck (served two ways), and seafood fried rice. The dan dan noodles weren't as spicy as I hoped but they were tasty. The Peking duck was first sliced table-side for us and served with sliced green onions and rice wrappers. The second part of the duck was served stir fried with lettuce wraps. I can't speak to the seafood fried rice as it didn't appeal to me that evening.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom

IurCei3hZdOp_9QKrokI3A.text: I was a little disappointed we tried to go for dinner around 4pm and they didn't have any tables available until 10:30pm so we went to the bar for drinks. It was very crowded and we were lucky to get the last two seats at the bar (there are also small tables in the bar area). It was slightly uncomfortable and boiling hot in the bar area.We were seated for about 5-8 minutes before any of the six bartenders even acknowledged us. They were very busy filling bar and table orders but also had their backs to us the whole time. We had to ask to order all of our drinks like we were interrupting them but when they did engage in conversation they were polite and seemed happy to chat.The drink menu has plenty of choices being 12 pages from signature cocktails, champagne, wines by the glass or bottle, to half bottles and virgin drinks. The cocktail options were in the £12-£18 range and the wines varying by type and region of the world. They did make the drinks with fresh juices, dried fruits and fresh garnishes. They had unique cocktails with varying liquor options too. We tried a gin drink, a tequila cocktail as well as a sambuca cocktail.  They were all very different but very refreshing and balanced.  I was a little disappointed in the small bite/snack selection.  There were olives, three spring roll options and not much else.By far you are paying for the incredible views being on the 31st-33rd floor of The Shard. The views are incredible,  even from the restroom and makes it worth the trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. View from the restroom
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Hallway
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Bar

bcWcZdF58Ce6AgY0A0jOdg.text: Well, the view was delicious and while we thought the food feel a little short of the Hong Kong location we still enjoyed it. The two detractions being the service and the Peking duck. Not bad but no Hong Kong. We still highly recommended, early dinner would be best time. Don't miss the men's restroom. Best dish shrimp ma la, but know it's hot.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Ma La Shrimp with chilies
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Men's room
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom

p13GJHcQFTre2TcQcivfNg.text: Like all restaurants at the Shard, they may have an incredible view but the food is fair at best. Hutong is very cool and the service was great. The dim sum menu is limited and overall very average. You definitely pay for the atmosphere but there are so many other phenomenal dim sum restaurants that this should not be on your list!

RBNjOVbt-jqbDiPWU1IFcg.text: Waited so long to dine here, excited and looking forward to a lovely anniversary dinner which turned into a 'should have just gone to a local Chinese'. Honestly had the worst experience only just started eating our starters when the mains arrived and was sat on the side table as they realised it was too early, then when we questioned it when trying to serve us cold mains they returned it and took it back. Only to then receive mains dishes that wasn't our order :-( took them the 4th time to actually serve us our actual order which we still found quite cold but at this point had just given up and wanted to go home. Don't think we will be going there again!

qQ3EQKUvoQBTYLAucZaruw.text: More of a scene than a fine dining establishment as the food is not terrible, but nothing to write about. Sometimes, the food is not the point. Hutong is atop the Shard, the tallest building in London, which affords spectacular vistas of the city.We dined at one of the private rooms, ordering pretty much the entire menu. The sommelier guided us in selecting our wine. The only thing I remember is the roast duck, quiet passable, and the fine bottle of champagne. Definitely pay a visit to the bathroom, which features fabulous views that you can enjoy while relieving yourself. The crowd outside the private room was lively, young and well dressed. So put on your nice clothes and have a night out.

VxhRhDI0wOQaAX6sj6RZsg.text: The view was exceptional.... truly fabulous.  The service was hit or miss.... mediocre overall with a rushed non-personalized feeling - less than I would expect for a restaurant of this price. My husband very much enjoyed the duck fat old fashioned he ordered pre-meal.  The food was good but not exceptional for the price (a solid 6.5 out of 10 I would say) and in particular, the veggie side dishes stood out (dim sum was a bit cold, the beef/broccoli was a bit grainy and the peking duck skin wasn't crisp though tasted delicious and the thin pancakes were perfection).The good news is, we came for the view... and with low expectations for the food and therefore, were pleasantly surprised overall and had a lovely time. My main recommendation for Hutong would be to clean up service a bit to create a more personalized feel to each encounter (and to find a way to make the kitchen door light a bit less bright into the dining room, everyone near us that sat at the table by the doors asked to be moved, luckily, we were one more table away and weren't bothered).

mUzNpgmPjFit_2SPssCzeQ.text: In hindsight my previous review seems a little harsh as I was perhaps expecting too much and comparing the quality of food to that of the best of Chinese cuisine, as is what I expected at Hutong's prices and being located at such a prime spot in the Shard.Now I have come to appreciate the simple elegance of Hutong's decor and the novelty of the fantastic view it has of London. I visited again during the mid-autumn festival season this year and they had made the evening more special by hiring a Chinese calligrapher to write names and phrases for all guests, which was a nice touch.The food on the whole was good, especially the soft shell crab, which was uniquely presented in a bed of dried chillis. However, other than the view outside the windows, nothing stands out as being that exceptional for me so Hutong is worth a visit for a special occasion but seems more of an expensive novelty than a quality Chinese restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom.  (CR, C) Red Lantern Crispy soft-shell crab with Sichuan dried chilli (34)
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Chef's special pickled vegetable fried rice (contains shreds of duck)
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom.    (S, C, SE) Chinkiang pork ribs  Pork short ribs braised with sweet vinegar sauce (28.50)

NpvgeizZyQiBS0urAqMkoQ.text: Given the usual Pub fare we've experienced, the better than average Asian flavors and incredible views, giving this place less tha 5 stars is selling it short.  Not saying I would go here every time I was in town, but I think everyone should definitely give it a try and see what they think.

lC5DR_RtvePM_uxj3qUfAQ.text: We found the staff extremely rude. We were a party of 2 and were given a corner table near the kitchen. When asked about transfering to other empty tables at nicer location, they declined saying other tables are 4 seater which is completely ridiculous given all the tables were same size. Anyways thought we were treated extremely un fairly. The overall atmosphere is extremely dark. Only good thing about this is the view. Other than that nothing appealing

Nl8QGqyMKEoWJgG8G2lJ7w.text: Made reservations here since we would be in the UK for a wedding. This place has very beautiful views and the service was great. I would say that getting here was pretty easy and easy to find. Mostly you're just paying for the view. Anywhere you're seated has a view of London. The food was great (ordered dim sum) but it's definitely not the dim sum I expected. It's overpriced for what you're getting and you can get better dim sum for a better price at any Chinatown. Plus there's really not a lot of variety which was disappointing. We came here during lunch time during the week and it was mostly business professionals stopping in. The wine and cocktail list though was impressive. My husband and I had a glass of wine and enjoyed the views. Altogether I would probably just recommend coming here for some drinks and not the food to enjoy the food.

TBPEHzHWzC1zPGLX6RTbdw.text: Celebrated my friend's graduation here, i have to agree with other reviewers that say you are paying mostly for the ambience. The restaurant is beautiful but the food is pretty average and really expensive.

zjYyJoPHGNRLKlza0ycq2g.text: We came here on a Monday night and made reservations for 6:30pm. Honestly,  you are really paying for the ambiance which is 5 stars and food was 4 Stars. The service was lacking. We had to flag down our server times in order to place our order and to get more drink orders. Also, felt like we were at an airport security. Make sure you arrive early because you have to literally go through security ... wait in line and then go through metal detectors and then you get to go to the elevator to the 32nd floor.

Epdz7_syF143ui7hNmnfGA.text: If you're interested in taking selfies with the best background possible...go to the Shard! While you're there, a stop at Hutong is worth every penny! I ordered the Crispy Beef with rice and it was delicious! Imagine shredded beef with julienne carrots flavored with the most delectable sauce you will ever taste. The sauce was sweet and tangy. Sooooo good! The ambience is very sexy and vibrant. Rich dark wood and Chinese lanterns with soft overhead lighting sets the mood effortlessly.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Tower Bridge from my table at Hutong
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Dinner with a view

hl3SqgPKZjW33MU9jw8gxQ.text: We ordered the kung pao shrimp and shrimp fried rice ... vegetable spring rolls for appetizers. Overall the food was solid. Nothing too impressive. I enjoyed the spring rolls and shrimp fried rice the best! Food is overpriced. We came to the restaurant by chance, without reservations and seating wasn't a problem. The view from the restaurant is amazing! You can see so much of London! Service was great! I think overall it was a decent experience.

UuXJT3gaP6k66Mm4j35vNg.text: We quite enjoyed the dim sum tasting here. Great view, great food, Service was good (nothing stood out as great)

LzdZkiiR8p_5qXmkPPv8-g.text: I have been coming to Hutong since they opened up.  Despite the fact I live in New York City, a trip to London for me is never complete without a stop at this iconic establishment.  Admittedly one has to plan ahead and make a reservation but once seated for a table the culinary and visual experience is breath taking.  On those instances when I could not be seated, the bar scene was lively even if service was a little slow.  All in all a good experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. All hail the duke.
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Awesome ginger ribs
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Spicy prawns.

9VbIGZRfHvLUAmtUzqiXvQ.text: Pleasantly Surprised...I had wanted to try Hutong for a while and my partner wanted dinner at The Shard so it made sense to get Hutong booked up! I had heard mixed things, read mixed reviews and was in some ways a bit nervous as it's a pricey dinner...I didn't want it to be rubbish!Luckily for me and my bank balance Hutong was great!We had a great table in the corner with windows surrounding us and a great view over Tower Bridge. The restaurant is quiet and relaxed with staff always available but never pushy.Food wise I think Hutong is better then Oblix, which is a good start. The prices are high but you get really good portion sizes. We went with the Half duck, the crispy beef, Prawn starter and Rice. I was a bit concerned it wouldn't be enough but it was plenty! The duck comes over two courses-a starter and then bascially another main so it's two dishes really. We actually preferred the 2nd dish of it.Drinks wise, My partner is doing dry Jan so I thought I would join her and we went for two of the virgin cocktails...they were amazing and in some ways better than a normal cocktail, and half the price!Overall I really enjoyed Hutong, the food is not ground breaking and there are much better/cheaper options in London overall. But for high end, Chinese food in a great setting Hutong is right up there!I think going with a group of 4 would be ideal to give you the chance to try more of the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Crispy Beef
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Prawns
Photo of Hutong - London, United Kingdom. Hutong View

cRGsUvXR4f7Xzp9hqnbkIg.text: Beyond the obvious incredible location and views, this place has nothing to offer. The food is so over priced and so underwhelming. Little flavor and all flourish makes the entire experience a disappointment. We ordered several starters and several entrees to share and there was not a single thing that I would call memorable or enjoyable. The beef in one of our dishes could have been chicken, could have been cardboard, could have been anything. The soft shell crab was dry and lacked flavor, it also was not cleaned properly so I ended up with a big bite of something not crab. And it is SO expensive. Not worth it. Go up to the bar for drinks (also not worth totally worth it) and the view and leave.
